question: What resources are acceptable for reserves?
answer: Library books, personal books, journal articles, book chapters (single chapter or 10 percent, whichever is LESS), files created by instructor, student papers with written permission of student author, and DVDs may all be put on reserve.

question: Will the library buy resources for my course?
answer: The library will consider purchasing **only** mandatory resources for courses if they are not currently owned. Each purchase, from physical books to electronic resources like streaming videos and eBooks, will be decided on based on cost and availability. Purchase requests can be made through the [online request form](https://uidaho.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_d3UL6u0pxEGpZs2) or by [emailing Reserves directly](mailto:libreserve@uidaho.edu).

question: How do I access materials from off-campus?
Can Harvard Business Review content be put on reserve?
answer: No, it cannot be linked via Leganto or Canvas. Instructors must ensure that the Library has access to the desired article, and students must search for articles themselves.

question: How do students find Harvard Business Review content?
answer: Some HBR resources are available through the [Business Source Premier](https://uidaho.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?site=bsi) and [ABI/INFORM Global](https://uidaho.idm.oclc.org/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/abiglobal?accountid=14551) databases. Students must be logged in to access full-text articles.

question: Where can I learn more about Leganto Integrated Course Reserves?
answer: Leganto is the Library's integrated course reserves platform that helps make course materials more accessible to students. Embedded directly into your Canvas course and connected to the library's resources, Leganto allows instructors to easily create and customize reading lists, so that students can access all their course materials in one place. Contact reserves [via email](mailto:libreserve) or by stop by the circulation desk to learn more. Check our [How to Activate Leganto in Canvas](/services/reserve/leganto.html) instructions to get started. Questions about or issues with Canvas should be direct to the [Center for Excellence in Teaching and Learning (CETL)](https://www.webpages.uidaho.edu/cetl/index.asp).

question: What are the requirements for scans?
answer: Scans are required to be clean and run through OCR software. If scans are not suitable for use, they will need to be re-done by Library staff. Staff will be in contact if the original text is needed for re-scanning.

question: How quickly will scans be processed?
answer: Scanning will be done by order of receipt, within a week for articles/book chapters. Further information on Controlled Digital Lending scanning can be found in the CDL section of this FAQ.

question: What do I need to know about copyright with reserves?
answer: Please [access our Copyright Guide](https://www.lib.uidaho.edu/copyright/guide.html), and direct any questions to the [reserves email](libreserve@uidaho.edu).

question: Why do I need written permission to use students' work or any unpublished work that is not my own?
answer: The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 (FERPA) protects any use of student papers without their written permission. You can use the [Library's Student Materials Permission Form](https://www.lib.uidaho.edu/pdf/studentMaterialsPermission.pdf) to obtain this permission.

question: Can I use resources successively?
answer: Materials can be used for one semester under provisions of the Fair Use sections of the copyright law. Subsequent use requires that the library purchase rights to re-use the item. In the event that these rights are denied or deemed to be beyond reasonable costs, the library will remove the item from reserve and contact the professor about securing different readings.

question: What is Controlled Digital Lending and how does it work for reserves?
answer: [Controlled Digital Lending (CDL)](https://controlleddigitallending.org/) is a way of providing digital access to books that are currently available only in a physical format, when the library is unable to find a licensing option for an existing e-book or e-resource. Library-owned books are scanned fully by staff and added to our catalog for use in reserves. Requests for CDL can be denied at the discretion of Library staff.

question: How much can I ask to be scanned for CDL?
answer: No more than 2 books for a total of no more than 800 pages can be requested for CDL by an instructor in a semester. Condition of the book and ability of book to be properly scanned may affect if books are able to be scanned.

question: How long will CDL scanning take?
answer: Scanning will take **at least** two weeks. Due to the time it takes to scan CDL items, requests should be submitted as promptly as possible.

question: How do students access CDL items?
answer: CDL scans will be available in the corresponding course reading list hosted on [Leganto](https://alliance-uidaho.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/leganto/public/01ALLIANCE_UID/searchlists). Users must be logged in. Access is limited to one user for three hours; a waitlist is available if the resource is in use and users will be notified when it is available.
